frameDefinitions: An Item is attached by a Handle, via a Connector, to a Goal, or Items are attached to each other.

The Attaching frame covers two situations: a scene in which somebody causes one thing to be physically connected to something else; or a scene in which somebody causes two things to be connected to each other.
A Member is semi-permanently part of a socially constructed Group.
A concept, Concept_1, is related causally or collocationally to another concept, Concept_2 by means of some evidence.

This frame involves a static (primarily spatial) relationship between a Location and a Theme, in which the Theme is located in many or all subregions of the Location, and is thus construable as covering it.
frameExamples: My thumb was <t>stuck</t> to the tube of glue.
The robber <t>tied</t> Harry to the chair.
Victor is <t>part</t> of the Red Crescent
listRoleDefinitions: <fen>Connector</fen> identifies the instrument used to attach and is usually expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.
<fen>Item</fen> identifies the entity that comes to be attached to the <fen>Goal</fen>.
<fen>Items</fen> identifies the plural items that are tied together, resulting in their mutual attachment.
<fen>Goal</fen> identifies the location to which the <fen>Item</fen>(s) is attached.

The <fen>Agent</fen> manipulates an object. <fen>Agent</fen> typically refers to animate beings, but is also extended to mechanical and other inanimate objects.  It is most frequently expressed as the external argument of verbs.
This role identifies the <fen>Item</fen> that the <fen>Agent</fen> attaches to the <fen>Goal</fen>.
<fen>Goal</fen> identifies the location to which an <fen>Item</fen> is attached.
The <fen>Connector</fen> forms the bond that maintains the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen> in a fixed position; it is usually expressed in a <ment>with</ment>-PP.
This role identifies the plural <fen>Items</fen> that are tied together, resulting in their mutual attachment.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects the <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Place</fen> where the <fen>Agent</fen> intentionally affects an <fen>Item</fen> or <fen>Items</fen>.
The person who belongs to a <fen>Group</fen>.
A set of people standing in a semi-permanent relationship together.
The time at which the <fen>Member</fen> is a member of the <fen>Group</fen>.
The location where the membership relationship holds.
The concept which is linked to <fen>Concept_2</fen>.  Generally expressed as the external argument.
The concept which is tied to <fen>Concept_1</fen>.  Generally expressed as a PP complement.
The two concepts expressed jointly.

The <fen>Theme</fen> in this frame is the object which is described as standing in some spatial relation to a particular <fen>Location</fen>.  <fen>Theme</fen> typically occurs as the External Argument or, with passives, as a PP Complement headed by 'with' or 'by'.
<fen>Location</fen> is the entity or area with respect to which the <fen>Theme</fen>'s spatial arrangement is described.  This frame element generally occurs as an NP Object.
The time at which the <fen>Theme</fen> occupies the <fen>Location</fen>.
listRoleExamples: The tarp is  tied down <fex>with a rope</fex>.
<fex>A handle</fex>  was affixed to the door.
The boat remained anchored <fex>to the coastline</fex>.
<fex>The robber</fex> tied Harry to the chair.
The robber tied <fex>Harry</fex> to the chair.
The robber tied Harry <fex>to the chair</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair  <fex>with a rope</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>at midnight</fex>.
The robber tied Harry to the chair <fex>in the basement</fex>.
Two <fex>members</fex> of the Red Cross were here about a donation
